title: 114_hr2712
content: The "Commonsense Reporting and Verification Act of 2015" includes provisions for a prospective reporting system, protection of dependent privacy, electronic statements, GAO studies, and an eligibility verification process for ACA subsidies. The Act may be cited as the "Commonsense Reporting and Verification Act of 2015". The "Commonsense Reporting and Verification Act of 2015" aims to minimize compliance burdens under the Affordable Care Act while protecting individual privacy. It includes provisions for a prospective reporting system, dependent privacy protection, electronic statements, GAO studies, and eligibility verification for ACA subsidies. The Act mandates the implementation of a voluntary prospective reporting system by the Secretary of the Treasury within 180 days. Employers can report information voluntarily, including their name, employer identification number, and certification of coverage. The Act mandates a voluntary reporting system for employers to report on coverage offered to employees, dependents, spouses, and part-time employees, ensuring it meets specific requirements outlined in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Act mandates a voluntary reporting system for employers to report on coverage offered to employees, dependents, spouses, and part-time employees, ensuring it meets specific requirements outlined in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. This includes information on affordability safe harbors, coverage availability for full-time employees, waiting periods, and a process for secure access to information by Exchanges, the Federal Marketplace Data Services Hub, and the Internal Revenue Service. The Act mandates a voluntary reporting system for employers to provide necessary information for eligibility determinations of premium tax credits and cost-sharing subsidies under the Affordable Care Act. This includes secure access to information by relevant agencies, follow-up with employers for additional information, and notification of eligibility issues to employees. The Act mandates a voluntary reporting system for employers to provide updates on coverage changes for employees. Employers using the system can fulfill IRS reporting requirements for the calendar year when a plan year ends. Employers can meet IRS reporting requirements by providing statements to the IRS and employees if they receive a notice from the Exchange regarding enrollment in a qualified health plan or eligibility for premium tax credits or subsidies under the Affordable Care Act. Employers can use third parties for IRS filing. Exchanges notify employers when employees enroll in health plans. SEC. 4 amends Section 6055(b) of the Internal Revenue Code to allow substitution of name and date of birth for TINs if not collected before 2014. Effective date is 60 days after enactment. SEC. 5 relates to electronic statements. Section 6056(c) of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to allow electronic delivery of statements if consent has been given by the individual to receive them electronically from their employer. Similarly, Section 6055(c) is amended to allow electronic delivery of statements relating to health insurance coverage. An individual consents to receive statements electronically if they have previously agreed to receive private health information electronically. The amendments apply to statements due after December 31, 2015. The GAO will conduct studies. The Comptroller General of the United States will conduct a study evaluating employer notifications by Exchanges under the Affordable Care Act regarding eligibility for tax credits and subsidies for full-time employees from 2014 to 2016. The study will evaluate employer notifications by Exchanges under the Affordable Care Act from 2014 to 2016, focusing on the process, sufficiency of information provided, total number of notifications sent, timeline, and differences in the notification process between marketplaces. The study will assess employer notifications by Exchanges under the Affordable Care Act from 2014 to 2016, focusing on the process, sufficiency of information, total number of notifications, timeline, differences between marketplaces, challenges in the notification process, and recommendations. Additionally, it will examine the establishment of a separate appeals process for employers to challenge eligibility determinations as required by the Act. The Comptroller General of the United States will conduct a study to evaluate the prospective reporting system established under section 3, focusing on the accuracy of information collected, employer participation, and implementation challenges. A report on the study results will be submitted to relevant Senate and House committees by July 1, 2018. The Comptroller General will submit a report to Senate and House committees by July 1, 2018, on the results of the study evaluating the prospective reporting system established under section 3. SEC. 7. ELIGIBILITY VERIFICATION PROCESS FOR ACA SUBSIDIES. A marketplace can automatically reenroll an individual in a qualified health plan annually, considering eligibility for subsidies and income changes. If the marketplace does not follow the specified processes, there are reenrollment limitations. The marketplace may not automatically reenroll an individual in a qualified health plan with subsidies until current income information is provided for redetermination. This section aligns with guidance on annual eligibility redeterminations and reenrollments issued by the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services in 2015. The marketplace must ensure that enrollees maintain authorization for disclosure of information, provide updated income details annually, and receive timely notices for redeterminations and reenrollments. The term "marketplace" refers to State Based Exchanges and the Federally Facilitated Exchange established under the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act.
